posts.text: If Congress is organised, it already has the power to take back responsibilities from the executive and make itself relevant. It should do so https://www.economist.com/leaders/2026/02/19/how-to-improve-american-legislators-lot
posts.author: TheEconomist

posts.text:
Gold demand is set to rise further this year:

Global gold demand is projected to rise to a record ~4,900 tonnes in 2026, marking the 2nd-consecutive annual increase.

Jewelry demand is expected to rise by +100 tonnes, to ~1,700 tonnes, the highest since 2024.

World central bank purchases are estimated to come in at a historically high ~1,000 tonnes.

Physical-backed gold ETFs are expected to record ~900 tonnes in net inflows for the 2nd-consecutive year.

Meanwhile, bar and coin demand is expected to remain steady at ~1,300 tonnes.

The world cannot get enough gold.
posts.author: KobeissiLetter

posts.text:
I would argue the opposite… Hydrograph is an Nanotech IP company that has been lost and unappreciated because it’s been marketing on the CSE amongst shitco miners.  

The audience is completely clueless to what Hydrograph $hg $hgraf is all about.   

Jaded investor group that doesn’t have a clue how to value it or if they should believe in it. So they have to wait for EPA approvals and other major milestones to see the forest through the trees. 

It’s moving to the Nasdaq and is now marketing to a world that is desperate for nanomaterials and graphene tech. Especially high tech applications and advanced biotech 

Very few mining guys got it… only the curious deep dive types.   Jay was willing to look. Guys like Doug Casey and Jim Rogers have been on the hunt for a viable graphene solution for ages.  They get it.
